stem: A client with a T6 spinal cord injury reports a severe headache and blurred vision. The nurse reviews the clinical data. Select the 4 most likely findings that require immediate intervention.

options.text: Diaphoresis above the level of the spinal cord injury
Complains of feeling cold and clammy
Oxygen saturation of 98% on room air

sections.title: Situation
sections.content: 07:00. Mr. Jones, a 55-year-old male with a T6 spinal cord injury, is reporting a sudden onset of severe headache and blurred vision. He is restless and anxious.

sections.title: Background
sections.content: Mr. Jones has a history of autonomic dysreflexia. He is normally normotensive. Bowel movement was two days ago. Foley catheter in place.

sections.title: Assessment
sections.content: 07:05. Patient is alert but agitated. Complains of a pounding headache and visual disturbances. Noted to have a flushed face and profuse sweating above the level of his injury. Auscultation reveals bradycardia. No new medications administered. No known allergies. Last vital signs were within normal limits at 06:00. Bladder scan shows 100mL urine.

sections.title: Recommendation
sections.content: I suspect Mr. Jones is experiencing autonomic dysreflexia. I recommend immediate blood pressure check, assessment for triggers, and possible medication administration to lower his blood pressure. Please expedite.

sections.title: General
sections.content: Alert and agitated male. Appears uncomfortable.

sections.title: Skin
sections.content: Flushed face and upper chest. Profuse sweating above the level of the umbilicus. Skin below umbilicus is cool and dry.

sections.title: Neurological
sections.content: Complains of severe headache and blurred vision. No motor or sensory deficits noted below the level of injury.

sections.title: Cardiovascular
sections.content: Bradycardia noted. No murmurs or gallops.

sections.title: Problem
sections.content: Risk for autonomic dysreflexia related to spinal cord injury.

sections.title: Goal
sections.content: Patient will maintain blood pressure within normal limits and report absence of symptoms of autonomic dysreflexia.

sections.title: Interventions
sections.content: Monitor blood pressure frequently. Assess for triggers. Administer medications as prescribed. Educate patient on prevention strategies.

rationale.opt_1: Correct. A systolic blood pressure of 210 mmHg is a hallmark sign of autonomic dysreflexia and requires immediate intervention to prevent complications such as stroke or seizure.
rationale.opt_2: Correct. Bradycardia (heart rate of 52 bpm) is a common finding in autonomic dysreflexia due to the baroreceptor reflex attempting to lower blood pressure.
rationale.opt_3: Correct. Flushed face and upper chest are indicative of vasodilation above the level of the spinal cord injury, a characteristic sign of autonomic dysreflexia.
rationale.opt_4: Correct. Diaphoresis (excessive sweating) above the level of the spinal cord injury is another key sign of autonomic dysreflexia due to the uninhibited sympathetic nervous system response.
rationale.opt_5: Incorrect. Feeling cold and clammy is not typically associated with autonomic dysreflexia, which usually presents with flushing and sweating above the level of injury.
rationale.opt_6: Incorrect. An oxygen saturation of 98% on room air is within normal limits and does not indicate autonomic dysreflexia.
rationale.opt_7: Incorrect. While a headache is a symptom of autonomic dysreflexia, it is not as immediately critical as the vital sign abnormalities and other physical findings.

clinicalPearls: Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency. Rapid recognition and intervention are crucial to prevent severe complications. Always prioritize assessing blood pressure and identifying the triggering stimulus.
questionTrap: The trap is to focus solely on the headache and miss the more critical vital sign abnormalities. The question requires prioritizing findings that indicate immediate physiological compromise.
mnemonic: The 4 Cardinal Signs of Autonomic Dysreflexia: B-Bradycardia, H-Hypertension, F-Flushing (above injury), S-Sweating (above injury)
